title: 107_s285
content: The Act may be cited as the "Water Conservation and Quality Incentives Act". Congress recognizes the increasing demands on water supplies due to factors like population growth and environmental needs. Water conservation and efficiency measures can help meet these demands and benefit various users. States that acknowledge rights to conserved water can incentivize conservation efforts. The Federal Government should provide financial assistance for implementing water conservation measures to meet changing water needs and improve water quality for various users. SEC. 3. USE OF STATE REVOLVING LOAN FUNDS FOR WATER CONSERVATION IMPROVEMENTS. Section 603 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow for construction of water conservation improvements by eligible recipients. The term 'eligible recipient' includes various entities such as municipalities, special districts, and nonprofit organizations. State agency, nonprofit private organization, or lending institution in a State with water conservation laws can receive financial assistance for constructing water conservation improvements like piping or lining irrigation canals. Financial assistance can be provided for water conservation improvements such as piping or lining irrigation canals, wastewater recycling, irrigation scheduling, water metering, on-field efficiency improvements, and other State-approved measures. Participation in these improvements is voluntary, and the conserved water must be allocated according to applicable State laws. Conserved water made available for water conservation improvements must comply with applicable State laws, including limitations on using the water for irrigated agriculture on previously non-irrigated land. SEC. 4. USE OF STATE REVOLVING LOAN FUNDS FOR WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS. Section 603 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include provisions for construction of water quality improvements by eligible recipients. Eligible recipients are defined as various entities including municipalities, tribal authorities, and nonprofit organizations. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow states to provide financial assistance for water quality improvements to eligible recipients. Participation in these improvements is voluntary. Section 601(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow for construction of water conservation and quality improvements by eligible recipients under specific subsections.
